poem:
**Peer Review**

In the House of Lords, a tale unfolds,  
of staircases regal and stories old.  
David of Watford, with a coveted smile,  
sells access as if royal style.  

The gilded halls echo the price,  
£25,000 for a taste of the spice.  
In the corridors where whispers roam,  
even prestige calls money home.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Lord Evans of Watford: long-serving peer facing cash-for-access questions The distinct interiors of the House of Lords fill the pages of the online brochure: the royal staircase, the robing room and the royal gallery. They provide a regal flavour of an event aimed at the construction industry – one that can be sponsored for up to £25,000. Next to a prominent picture of Lord David Evans of Watford sitting smiling in the royal gallery is". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
